column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=VI
#Text=On A bright sunshiny day , with the breeze chasing her smoke far ahead , the Nan-Shan came into Fu-chau .
#Text=Her arrival was at once noticed on shore , and the seamen in harbour said :
#Text=“ Look !
#Text=Look at that steamer .
#Text=What 's that ?
#Text=Siamese -- is n't she ?
#Text=Just look at her ! ”
#Text=She seemed , indeed , to have been used as a running target for the secondary batteries of a cruiser .

#Text=A hail of minor shells could not have given her upper works a more broken , torn , and devastated aspect : and she had about her the worn , weary air of ships coming from the far ends of the world -- and indeed with truth , for in her short passage she had been very far ; sighting , verily , even the coast of the Great Beyond , whence no ship ever returns to give up her crew to the dust of the earth .

#Text=She was incrusted and gray with salt to the trucks of her masts and to the top of her funnel ; as though ( as some facetious seaman said ) “ the crowd on board had fished her out somewhere from the bottom of the sea and brought her in here for salvage . ”
#Text=And further , excited by the felicity of his own wit , he offered to give five pounds for her -- “as she stands . ”

#Text=Before she had been quite an hour at rest , a meagre little man , with a red-tipped nose and a face cast in an angry mould , landed from a sampan on the quay of the Foreign Concession , and incontinently turned to shake his fist at her .
#Text=A tall individual , with legs much too thin for a rotund stomach , and with watery eyes , strolled up and remarked , “ Just left her -- eh ?
#Text=Quick work . ”

#Text=He wore a soiled suit of blue flannel with a pair of dirty cricketing shoes ; a dingy gray moustache drooped from his lip , and daylight could be seen in two places between the rim and the crown of his hat .
#Text=“ Hallo !
#Text=what are you doing here ? ” asked the ex-second-mate of the Nan-Shan , shaking hands hurriedly .
#Text=“ Standing by for a job -- chance worth taking -- got a quiet hint , ” explained the man with the broken hat , in jerky , apathetic wheezes .
#Text=The second shook his fist again at the Nan-Shan .
#Text=“ There 's a fellow there that ai n't fit to have the command of a scow , ” he declared , quivering with passion , while the other looked about listlessly .
#Text=“ Is there ? ”
#Text=But he caught sight on the quay of a heavy seaman 's chest , painted brown under a fringed sailcloth cover , and lashed with new manila line .
#Text=He eyed it with awakened interest .
#Text=“ I would talk and raise trouble if it was n't for that damned Siamese flag .
#Text=Nobody to go to -- or I would make it hot for him .
#Text=The fraud !
#Text=Told his chief engineer -- that 's another fraud for you -- I had lost my nerve .
#Text=The greatest lot of ignorant fools that ever sailed the seas .
#Text=No ! You ca n't think . . . ”
#Text=“ Got your money all right ? ” inquired his seedy acquaintance suddenly .
#Text=“ Yes .
#Text=Paid me off on board , ” raged the second mate .
#Text=“ '
#Text=Get your breakfast on shore , ' says he . ”
#Text=“ Mean skunk ! ” commented the tall man , vaguely , and passed his tongue on his lips .
#Text=“ What about having a drink of some sort ? ”
#Text=“ He struck me , ” hissed the second mate .
#Text=“ No ! Struck ! You do n't say ? ”
#Text=The man in blue began to bustle about sympathetically .
#Text=“ Ca n't possibly talk here .
#Text=I want to know all about it . Struck -- eh ?
#Text=Let 's get a fellow to carry your chest .
#Text=I know a quiet place where they have some bottled beer . . . . ”
#Text=Mr. Jukes , who had been scanning the shore through a pair of glasses , informed the chief engineer afterwards that “ our late second mate has n't been long in finding a friend .
#Text=A chap looking uncommonly like a bummer .
#Text=I saw them walk away together from the quay . ”
#Text=The hammering and banging of the needful repairs did not disturb Captain MacWhirr .
#Text=The steward found in the letter he wrote , in a tidy chart-room , passages of such absorbing interest that twice he was nearly caught in the act .
#Text=But Mrs. MacWhirr , in the drawing-room of the forty-pound house , stifled a yawn -- perhaps out of self-respect -- for she was alone .
#Text=She reclined in a plush-bottomed and gilt hammock-chair near a tiled fireplace , with Japanese fans on the mantel and a glow of coals in the grate .
#Text=Lifting her hands , she glanced wearily here and there into the many pages .
#Text=It was not her fault they were so prosy , so completely uninteresting -- from “ My darling wife ” at the beginning , to “ Your loving husband ” at the end .
#Text=She could n't be really expected to understand all these ship affairs .
#Text=She was glad , of course , to hear from him , but she had never asked herself why , precisely .
#Text=“ . . .
#Text=They are called typhoons . . .
#Text=The mate did not seem to like it . . .
#Text=Not in books . . .
#Text=Could n't think of letting it go on . . . . ”
#Text=The paper rustled sharply . “ . . . .
#Text=A calm that lasted more than twenty minutes , ” she read perfunctorily ; and the next words her thoughtless eyes caught , on the top of another page , were :
#Text=“ see you and the children again . . . . ”
#Text=She had a movement of impatience .
#Text=He was always thinking of coming home .
#Text=He had never had such a good salary before .
#Text=What was the matter now ?
